General humour

Humour is widely interpreted

Not everything here is meant to be laugh out loud - some is just amusing stories.

Stories

This story where Lori Baker‚Äôs husband (and Lori herself) are alerted by accident to fact that her Tetris playing ability is world champion level - and according to this leaderboard the record she set is still in the top 5 in the world. (Ending of story does rather lean into sexist division of labour.)

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt the 1800s. You can‚Äôt pay me with a horse‚Äù - I think Donald J. Trump has a reputation for trying to reduce the amount he pays suppliers - not an amusing tendency in general but this time it went somewhere funny.

How slow is the world‚Äôs fastest aircraft? A pilot recounts the slowest he went in a Lockheed SR-71 (even in 2022 apparently the fastest airbreathing manned aircraft).

This is the reporter Damon Green‚Äôs story on how this interview happened. It is a less serious version of the Jeremy Paxman/William Hague interview - where Paxman goes through some version of ‚Äúyou asked him?‚Äù nine times to try and get an answer re: Lord Ashcroft‚Äôs tax status. Beyond the ironic humour and surreal elements of Green‚Äôs story the serious point is the issues with politicians not giving anything away that is not a prepared soundbite.

Unintended consequences

Stories of Americans not paying attention to the public health information that suggests they have coronavirus are stories with the capacity to amuse but aren‚Äôt really funny - it is an attitude getting people sick or dead at the population level. But the following at least is in Shanghai where, if not universally competently, the government actually has an anti-COVID plan that targets coronavirus infections rather than ‚Äúpolitically unacceptable levels of death from COVID‚Äù. So here this is:

Loose translation: a Japanese guy got Covid-19 in Shanghai a little while ago so the city published a list of places he went for contact tracing‚Ä¶which people are now using as a restaurant guide for authentic Japanese food in the city https://t.co/1MVXr5wNKd

‚Äî Gavin Cross (@thanksgaving) December 21, 2021

Footnote

Re: Cutler paper: try reading the paper out loud yourself or if that is no better try a web search about the paper/ask a few native English speakers to try reading out loud to see if they do it differently than you do.
